"The long middle of a story is the hardest part for me as a writer. The beginning, far in the past. The endingâ€”I donâ€™t know. But what I do know is that it is good for a writer to be unaware of the conclusion. If the end startles the writer, it likely will surprise the reader, too. Pssstâ€”the hero dies. I didn't hear that. I used to think that writing was a ticket to immortality. Who needed children when oneâ€™s progeny was oneâ€™s books? In my teens and early 20s, I longed for fame and glory. I didnâ€™t think much about how the names of the immortals were relatively few, while libraries were filled with thousands of books by writers I had never heard of before, some of them quite famous in their time. And some authors whose names dominated only a decade or two ago are rarely mentioned today, now that their life force no longer animates the literary scene. When it comes to literary fameâ€”which is not really that famousâ€”I have more than some authors and less than others. But whenever I am tempted to believe my own hype, I read my one-star reviewsâ€”Bafflingly overpraised! Absurdist and repulsive! Pure garbage!â€”and recall that I live not far from Hollywood. When I tell people in Los Angeles that Iâ€™m a writerâ€”no one cares. And if no one cares, why should I? That seems to be the greatest freedom in being mid, at least for me. To be middle-aged is not necessarily to be mid, particularly if one feels that one is at the peak of oneâ€™s powers. In order to reduce and manage stress we all need to have a personal self care program if we are to stay healthy and function well. A few people asked about the process of writing a book, so here goes: 1. Write it. This took me only a few weeks, however there was a much bigger version of how to survive life as a dr that was abandoned and went under the bed - so First Aid was born of the bigger project. 2. Have someone proof read/edit it - essential. I was lucky and had 2 journalist friends who did this as a favour. Otherwise - there are various people you can pay to do this. If you look up Joanna Penn online, she recommends various people. 3. Typesetting - after a painful process trying Word (which is possible), I bought the Vellum software - only for Mac and Â£Â£ but extremely easy and a joy to use. Lacks a few features for non fiction eg tables etc. Amazon KDP also has something which works fine. 4. Cover: I paid a designer in the US not realising the markets and tastes are totally differentâ€¦ the results were not nice. (A â€œburned outâ€ teddy bear with a stethoscope around its neck. No, I donâ€™t know what got into their heads either). I did my own on Canva in the end. Thereâ€™s a lot more to that as your colours need to harmonise. Generally, the industry view is itâ€™s much better to pay a designer but this just didnâ€™t work out for me. 5. Upload to Amazon KDP. If you want to create a paperback then the cover has to be sized correctly - you can use a template called Bookow for this. 6. Launch. At every stage there is a, â€˜WTF am I doing?â€™ feeling and there will also be people who say, â€˜what are you doing, you seem to spend a lot of time on this,â€™ etc etc. So at every stage it helps to know the people who support you and your â€œwhyâ€ of the whole project.
